docs.lead_paragraph: CHRIS LONDON remembers the first time an impotence drug came to his emotional rescue. A 41-year-old lawyer and executive recruiter in Manhattan, Mr. London had been on a few dates with a lawyer who told him she couldn't judge a man without first having sex with him. The two made plans to meet after work, and Mr. London said he felt pretty certain about what was going to happen. He also felt not a little anxious. ''She was very wired -- a Samantha on 'Sex and the City'-type thing,'' he said. ''She made it like it was this test -- like passing the bar. I'm thinking to myself, I haven't had this sort of performance anxiety since I was 17.''

headline.main: In an Oversexed Age, More Guys Take a Pill

docs.abstract: Article on Chris London and increasing number of other sexually healthy men, many in their 20's, 30's and 40's, who doctors and sex therapists say are using impotence drugs--Viagra, Levitra and Cialis--as psychological palliatives against expectations of modern romance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a narrow office at the Westchester Medical Center here, Andrew Stasko reached into his desk and produced a business card: ''Chief of Cardiac Perfusion,'' it read. A bleak smile creased his face, which was framed by a blue surgical cap and a mask that dangled loosely around his neck. ''Take it,'' he said. ''It won't be any good after Jan. 10.''

headline.main: Our Towns; A Hobson's Choice at a Hospital in Valhalla: A Cut in Pay, or No Job

docs.abstract: Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, NY, notifies about 200 employees that they will be dismissed because of $16.5 budget deficit, but offers some a chance to stay on if they agree to pay cuts and demotions; their union blames poor financial management for cutbacks, noting that hospital stopped operating under auspices of county when it became public benefit corporation; hospital says union rebuffed its request for contract concessions to close budget gap and prevent layoffs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Noroton section of Darien is defined by two peninsulas that claw their way into Long Island Sound, their curved appendages protecting enough coves and inlets to make the area a haven for beachgoers and sailors. From there, Noroton spreads inland across the congestion of the Boston Post Road, then over Interstate 95 and the train tracks into the closely packed commuter neighborhoods of Noroton Heights. It is the water, however, that gives Noroton both its name -- an Indian word assigned to the river along Darien's border with Stamford -- and its identity. The shorter of the peninsulas, Noroton Neck, is divided into shore communities like Noroton Bay and Pratt Island, both notable for their multimillion-dollar properties. A new four-bedroom colonial on the Pratt Island waterfront was recently listed at $5.69 million. The peninsula is also home to the world-renowned Noroton Yacht Club, whose former members have included two America's Cup skippers. The club currently runs the largest junior sailing program in Fairfield County.

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/Noroton and Noroton Heights; A Haven for Both Sailors and Commuters

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Medicare bill that President Bush signed into law on Monday could be a boon for health insurers. The law contains a new prescription drug benefit, but there is much more to it than that. Charles Boorady, an analyst who follows the managed-care industry at Smith Barney, talked last week about the implications of the legislation. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

docs.lead_paragraph: Employees of Kroger supermarkets in West Virginia, Kentucky and Ohio ratified a new contract, ending their two-month strike against the Cincinnati chain over medical coverage. Kroger agreed to increase its contribution toward union health benefits by 10.5 percent. The Kroger Company also owns Ralphs, a Southern California chain where workers have been on strike since Oct. 11.

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: West Virginia: Kroger Strikers Ratify Contract

docs.abstract: Kroger employees in West Virginia end two-month strike, ratifying contract that improves health benefits by 10.5 percent (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Stalking the Giant Chicken Coop'' (column, Dec. 8), Bob Herbert's claim that Medicare is being dismantled may very well be true. But the real issue is that this new law is merely another attempt to treat the symptom and not the root cause of our ailing health care system.

headline.main: Making the Medical Care System Fair for All

docs.abstract: George Rehrey letter sys new Medicare law treats only symptom, not root cause, of ailing health care system

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey legislators voted on Thursday on measures that would prohibit drivers from using hand-held cellphones, lower the legal threshold for drunken driving and guarantee same-sex couples access to a wider range of medical insurance and legal protections. But as members of the Assembly and the State Senate rushed to act on an assortment of bills before the next legislative session begins in January, many lawmakers conceded that this lame-duck period, which ends in three weeks, was turning out to be even less eventful than expected.

headline.main: Legislators Focus on Lesser Issues After Failing to Increase Gas Tax

docs.abstract: New Jersey legislators are expected to focus on minor measures, including bill governing use of cellphones while driving, after failing to pass gas tax increase (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said Wednesday that it would monitor the prices of prescription drugs bought by Medicare beneficiaries to ensure they are not overcharged when they start using drug discount cards next June. The discount card program was authorized by the new Medicare law as a temporary measure to help elderly and disabled people until the full-fledged drug benefit becomes available on Jan. 1, 2006.

headline.main: Medicare to Monitor Prices in New Drug Plan

docs.abstract: Bush administration says that it will monitor prices of prescription drugs bought by Medicare beneficiaries to ensure they are not overcharged when they start using drug discount cards in June 2004 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The pharmacy benefit companies that manage drug coverage for most working Americans commonly offer millions of dollars in payments to important customers when contracts with them are signed, according to industry executives and consultants. The practice is receiving widespread attention after Justice Department officials on Tuesday accused Medco Health Solutions, one of the largest pharmacy benefit managers, of violating kickback laws by paying $87.4 million to Oxford Health Plans.

headline.main: Payments By Managers Of Drug Plans Face Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Practice by pharmacy benefit companies that manage drug coverage to offer millions of dollars in payments to important customers when contract with them are signed is receiving widespread attention after Justice Department accuses Medco Health Solutions of violating kickback laws by paying $87.4 million to Oxford Health Plans; Medco and Oxford, which received money two years ago, say payments were legal and appropriate; some industry experts say such payments often add to drug costs that pharmacy benefit managers were hired to shrink; Mark Campbell, chief executive of pharmacy benefit manager Innoviant, says it is not uncommon for number of pharmacy benefit managers to offer prospective customers up to $10 per covered person, theoretically to cover transition costs of installing new contract; adds Innoviant does not (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR 32 days, William Wessling, a 44-year-old chef in Pineville, N.C., was forced to stay out of his condominium because of a sore throat, pains in his fingers and neck and other ailments that his doctors attributed to mold behind his baseboards and kitchen cabinets. After $3,300 to clean out the mold, Mr. Wessling is spending nearly $2,000 on doors, gutters and grading to make sure it doesn't comes back. ''It was nasty,'' Mr. Wessling said. ''It can sneak up on you.''
docs.abstract: Toxic mold began making headlines decade ago, and has been blamed for array of health problems; claims are increasing and new products are being introduced to combat mold, but some experts are questioning whether molds actually cause these problems; there are 10,000 active lawsuits involving mold in homes; many insurers no longer cover claims related to mold and 43 states have made it legal for homeowner policies to exclude mold coverage; preventive measures for builders noted; photos; chart illustrates rising payouts by insurance companies (L)
